content.raw: I still think the yaml file is useful, I was suggesting we just remove the default file. But if you really want to get rid of it, I just have a few more suggestions on pull request #91.
content.html: I still think the yaml file is useful, I was suggesting we just remove the default file. But if you really want to get rid of it, I just have a few more suggestions on pull request #91.

content.raw: Since we're using the `default` branch, should we care about tick-tock?
content.html: Since we're using the default branch, should we care about tick-tock?

content.raw: If I do `ign fuel list -t model -u https://staging-api.ignitionfuel.org/`, I first get all the models for `https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org`, and then I get the ones for `https://staging-api.ignitionfuel.org/`. I'd expect to get only the list for the given server.
content.html: If I do ign fuel list -t model -u https://staging-api.ignitionfuel.org/, I first get all the models for https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org, and then I get the ones for https://staging-api.ignitionfuel.org/. I'd expect to get only the list for the given server.

This establishes the default fuel server in code, rather than in a config.yaml file. This follows the principle of making the default simple with requiring a special configuration.

update.title: Part 5: Hardcode default fuel server.

content.raw: @nkoenig, based on the comment above, how do you feel about removing the default yaml file in this PR?
content.html: @nkoenig, based on the comment above, how do you feel about removing the default yaml file in this PR?

content.raw:
Good point about versioning.

About only providing multiple server functionality through code, I think this would push the burden to downstream libraries if they want to expose the configuration to their users. i.e. ign-gazebo will need to expose that through a configuration file of its own.

I'm not sure about removing the configuration files altogether. The functionality is already implemented, tested and works. And it's handy for development, I often use the staging web server.

I could be convinced of removing the default yaml file though, and relying on the hardcoded values instead - I think this PR basically makes the default yaml useless.
content.html:
Good point about versioning.

About only providing multiple server functionality through code, I think this would push the burden to downstream libraries if they want to expose the configuration to their users. i.e. ign-gazebo will need to expose that through a configuration file of its own.

I'm not sure about removing the configuration files altogether. The functionality is already implemented, tested and works. And it's handy for development, I often use the staging web server.

I could be convinced of removing the default yaml file though, and relying on the hardcoded values instead - I think this PR basically makes the default yaml useless.

content.raw:
I would like to get rid of the yaml file. It's prone to error on a couple different fronts:

1. If you have a config.yaml file installed, then fuel-tools will not overwrite it. If a user changes the file incorrectly, then they cannot get back to working state unless they delete the file.
2. We can't change the default and allow two versions of ign-fuel-tools to live side-by-side. We could version the file if we really want to keep it.
3. Historically, any configuration file will lead to user error which is why we try to move away from things like `setup.bash`. 

Supporting multiple servers, and the yaml  file were added without a need or user. We can keep multiple server functionality via the C api, but I'd prefer to eliminate the yaml file. This is the first step toward that.
content.html:
I would like to get rid of the yaml file. It's prone to error on a couple different fronts:

  1. If you have a config.yaml file installed, then fuel-tools will not overwrite it. If a user changes the file incorrectly, then they cannot get back to working state unless they delete the file.
  2. We can't change the default and allow two versions of ign-fuel-tools to live side-by-side. We could version the file if we really want to keep it.
  3. Historically, any configuration file will lead to user error which is why we try to move away from things like setup.bash.

Supporting multiple servers, and the yaml file were added without a need or user. We can keep multiple server functionality via the C api, but I'd prefer to eliminate the yaml file. This is the first step toward that.

This establishes the default fuel server in code, rather than in a config.yaml file. This follows the principle of making the default simple with requiring a special configuration.

A user that doesn't want the default server can call `Clear`.
update.title: Part 5: Hardcode default fuel server.

content.raw:
Could you comment on the motivation for this change? Was the yaml file not working as the default, or was there a case that wasn't addressed?

Note that this changes actually makes the default hardcoded in 2 separate places: in the C++ code, and in the default yaml file.
content.html:
Could you comment on the motivation for this change? Was the yaml file not working as the default, or was there a case that wasn't addressed?

Note that this changes actually makes the default hardcoded in 2 separate places: in the C++ code, and in the default yaml file.

content.raw: When loading a custom configuration, I'd expect the default to be overridden instead of appending to it. Having to call `Clear` before `LoadConfig` feels counter-intuitive to me.
content.html: When loading a custom configuration, I'd expect the default to be overridden instead of appending to it. Having to call Clear before LoadConfig feels counter-intuitive to me.
